entry.title: Re: SAP Business ByDesign - OData API Examples
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I'm currently working on automating Supplier Invoice creation using the **ManageSupplierInvoiceIn** SOAP API in SAP Business ByDesign. I'm facing an issue with **Custom Business Object** fields that are mandatory in our Korean tenant.

**Current Situation:**
- Successfully creating Supplier Invoices via `ManageSupplierInvoiceIn` API in US tenant
- Korean tenant has a mandatory **SubTaxCode** field which is a **Custom Business Object** (not an Extension Field)
- The SubTaxCode field technical path: `/Root/DataList[1FF71396C0451EDEA19CA905D3DF1853]/SubCode`
- This Custom Business Object does not appear in the WSDL downloaded from Communication Arrangement

**Questions:**
1. **Can the standard SOAP API `ManageSupplierInvoiceIn` handle Custom Business Object fields?** If yes, how should they be included in the XML payload?

2. **If not possible with standard SOAP API, what alternative technology should I use to create Supplier Invoices with Custom Business Object data?**
- Custom Web Service API via SAP Cloud Applications Studio?
- OData API for Business Objects?
- Two-step process (create SI + update Custom BO separately)?

**Additional Context:**
- Extension Fields (like BrandGroup, Channel) work fine in the same API
- SubTaxCode is mandatory and appears in Item level in UI
- Looking for the most efficient solution for automated invoice processing

**Environment:** SAP Business ByDesign
**API:** ManageSupplierInvoiceIn (SOAP)

Any guidance or experience sharing would be greatly appreciated!

@knutheusermann @HarshalVakil @gerdb42 @alannahngaire @carlonnheim

entry.title: Re: Calculo de bases para el SDI
entry.content:
Hallo @rgonzalez11 

Danke für die Frage.

Unten habe ich eine kurze Zusammenfassung zur Generierung des Lohnartenkonzepts /37P im mexikanischen SDI-Abrechnungsprozess zusammengestellt:

Die Lohnart /37P mit einem variabler SDI-Anteil wird in der Regel MXVJ erzeugt.

Die bekannte Grundlage dafür sind alle relevanten Werte, die zuvor als /37C integrierbare Konzepte durch die Regel MXS1 und Funktion MXSI gebildet wurden.

/37P ist kein einfacher Summenwert der letzten Monate, sondern sie stellt einen nach gesetzlichen Vorgaben berechneten Tagesdurchschnitt aus /37C dar. Zum Beispiel im 2-Monatszeitraum.

Die Berechnungsdetails findest du direkt im Regelwerk von MXVJ oder im Payroll-Log (Transaktion PC00_M99_CALC_SIMU).

Bester Gruss

Chris

entry.title: Sales BOM: Is PGI for Both Parent and Child Components Possible in S/4HANA Cloud?
entry.content:
Dear Experts,


During delivery of sales BOM, client wants to do PGI for both parent and child component. Is that possible?


But we are unable to do PGI for child components, only possible to do parent component. Which is also not correct.


Kindly provide solution ASAP.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Sales BOM: Is PGI for Both Parent and Child Component...
entry.content:
Hi,

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it is not supported to perform PGI (Post Goods Issue) for both the parent and child components of a Sales BOM within the same delivery.

This is due to the standard behavior of Sales BOM item categories:

  • ERLA (Sales Set) → Only the parent item is delivery-relevant; child items are not picked or posted.
  • LUMF (Sales Kit) → Only the child components are delivery-relevant; the parent acts as a non-delivery header.

SAP Public Cloud does not support mixed PGI scenarios (i.e., issuing both levels in one delivery), especially if project stock (Q-stock) or special stock types are involved. There is also no standard config to allow dynamic switching between item category behaviors.

Workaround:

As a workaround, you may need to:

  • Split the process: Issue the parent and child items in separate deliveries, if business process allows.

Reference

Bills of Material in Sales Documents Help Portal

Hope this clarifies !

SAP Support

entry.title: Modernizing ERP and Data to Unlock the Power of Business AI
entry.content:
In the era of digital transformation, businesses are increasingly turning to innovative technologies to drive growth, improve efficiency, and stay competitive. Among these technologies, Artificial Intelligence (AI) stands out as a powerful force reshaping the landscape of enterprise operations. But before organizations can fully embrace AI, they must first lay the essential groundwork: modernizing their Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems and, crucially, their data.

This will be the main focus of an upcoming webinar - Modernizing ERP and data to unlock the power of Business AI.

The Twin Pillars of Transformation: ERP and Data

Many businesses recognize the value of updating their ERP systems, moving away from legacy platforms that can be rigid, siloed, and costly to maintain. Modern cloud-based ERPs offer agility, scalability, and integration, features essential for today’s fast-paced markets. However, the full benefits of these systems can only be realized when paired with a robust, modernized data foundation.

Without clean, organized, accessible, and secure data, even the most advanced ERP will struggle to deliver meaningful results. Modernizing data involves consolidating disparate sources, cleaning legacy records, ensuring consistency, and implementing governance protocols—all of which are vital for accurate analytics and AI applications.

Laying the Groundwork for AI Success

AI thrives on data. Its algorithms learn, adapt, and make predictions based on the quality and volume of information available. For businesses, this means that the path to unlocking AI-driven insights begins with data modernization. By creating a unified, high-quality data environment, organizations empower AI tools to generate actionable intelligence, automate routine tasks, and enable smarter decision-making.

Modern cloud ERP platforms are designed with AI in mind, making it easier for companies to deploy AI solutions across finance, supply chain, human resources, and beyond. For example, predictive analytics can forecast demand, optimize inventory, or identify patterns in customer behavior—driving efficiency and competitive advantage.

Benefits Beyond Efficiency: Agility and Competitive Edge

The synergy between modern ERP and data architecture goes beyond operational efficiency. Businesses gain agility—the ability to pivot in response to market changes, scale quickly, and innovate faster than ever before. With AI-powered insights, organizations can anticipate trends, personalize customer experiences, and automate complex workflows.

Moreover, this transformation is not just about technology. It’s a strategic investment in future readiness. As AI continues to evolve, businesses with a strong ERP and data foundation will be best positioned to leverage new breakthroughs, from natural language processing to advanced machine learning models.

Come join us on September 18th to discuss:

  • Why ERP and data modernization must go hand-in-hand
  • How cloud ERP provides a solid foundation for AI initiatives
  • The critical role of data in enabling accurate and actionable AI

Register here - Modernizing ERP and data to unlock the power of Business AI.

entry.title: Stop AI Model Disasters: The Application Owner's Guide to Bulletproof Deployments
entry.content:
So, you've deployed a fantastic application, leveraging the power of SAP‘s Generative AI Hub (linked reference architecture)! That's a significant step towards building intelligent business processes.

As a quick reminder: SAP’s Generative AI Hub is part of the AI Foundation. SAP’s AI Foundation, similar to an operating system provides the means to build, extend, and run custom AI solutions and agents at scale. It includes the generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, which is a rich set of AI capabilities (40+ frontier AI models, orchestration, SDKs, etc.), for productive purpose, running on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

Your application runs on BTP, and LLM technology powers the intelligence behind it. But here's what you can't delegate: managing the LLM’s Lifecycle for your application.

 

Understanding Model Lifecycle: A Key Distinction

Before diving into the model lifecycle, let's clarify the different ways you can leverage AI models:

  • Your self-hosted Models: You bring your own models (e.g., fine-tuned open-source models, proprietary models) and deploy them. This is akin to a Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) offering, where you manage the model artifacts, their dependencies, and their whole lifecycle on your own.  This gives you maximum flexibility: you can select, customize, and optimize models to fit your exact needs, including full control over versioning and performance. However, with that freedom comes responsibility. You’re in charge of the full lifecycle — from infrastructure and scaling to security, compliance, monitoring, costs and updates.
  • SAP Managed Models: This is comparable to a Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) offering. The Generative AI Hub provides pre-integrated, managed access to various LLMs from leading providers (i.e Azure OpenAI GPT-5, Google Gemini 2.5 Pro, AWS Claude Sonnet 4, etc.). It's important to understand that you do not need to acquire separate licenses for these LLMs; SAP handles the commercial agreements and technical integration. Furthermore, SAP takes on the responsibility for data privacy and security or confidentiality standards, related to the LLMs consumed through the Generative AI Hub, significantly reducing your operational burden.

For the following we focus on the latter. LLMs, the powerful engines behind generative AI, are constantly evolving. Model providers release new versions, older versions might be retired, and factors like performance and cost can change, as indicated by the graphic below. This dynamic environment means that the specific LLM version your application relies on today might not be available tomorrow.

 

Why Does This Matter to You, the Application Owner?

Here's the reality: AI models get retired. Your application depends on them. Without a lifecycle management strategy, you're one model retirement away from downtime —and missing out on better quality from newer models.

Moreover, different model versions may offer significantly better performance. A newer model might produce more accurate summaries which can directly impact your application's quality, user satisfaction, and business outcomes. Not updating could mean missing out on substantial improvements in capability, efficiency, or cost-effectiveness.

Your Role: Stay Informed, Be Prepared

Your primary responsibility regarding the model lifecycle is to:

  • Stay informed about the models supported by the SAP’s Generative AI Hub, including their versions, capabilities, cost, and most importantly, their retirement dates.
  • Have a plan for upgrading your application's model configuration when necessary.

Let's have a look on how you can fulfill these responsibilities using the tools and information available.

Staying Informed: Where to Find Model Information

SAP’s Generative AI Hub provides several ways to discover and understand the available LLMs:

  • SAP Notes:

    The central source of truth for supported models is SAP Note 3437766. This note provides comprehensive information, including the list of available models, supported versions, token conversion rates, rate limits, and retirement dates. Regularly checking this note is essential. You can access it via https://me.sap.com/notes/3437766. Crucially, you can subscribe to this SAP Note (indicated by the star icon) to receive automatic notifications via email about any changes, ensuring you're always up-to-date.

  • SAP AI Launchpad (UI):

    It's the natural place for an application owner to explore the Model Library and discover available models and their details. The Model Library also supports through comparison functionalities like the Leaderboard tab. Here you can see similar or better performing models.

  • Discovery API Endpoint:

    For programmatic access or detailed inspection, you can use the discovery API endpoint. By sending a GET request to the {{apiurl}}/v2/lm/scenarios/{scenarioid}/models endpoint, you can retrieve a list of all available models, their versions, capabilities, and retirement dates. This is a powerful tool for checking information dynamically. Find further information about that on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

By utilizing these resources, you can proactively identify when the model your application relies on is approaching its retirement date and plan your next steps.

Taking Action: Upgrading Your Model

When it's time to switch to a newer model version (preceded by tests/benchmarks), you have two main strategies, decided during the initial deployment configuration:

  • Auto Upgrade (modelVersion: latest):

    • How it works: When you create your generative AI configuration for a specific LLM, either through orchestration API or as a deployment, you can set the modelVersion parameter to latest. This will automatically use the most recent version of the specified model that is supported.
    • Pros: Less manual effort. As we support newer versions, your deployment will automatically shift, potentially giving you access to model improvements without intervention.
    • Cons: Less control. Your application might suddenly start using a new model version which, although intended to be compatible, could introduce subtle changes in behavior or performance that you haven't explicitly tested. This can be particularly problematic if your application relies on consistent LLM output behavior. Furthermore, it won't help in the situation of moving to different models (i.e. GPT-4.1 to GPT-5).

  • Manual Upgrade (Specify <modelVersion>):

    • How it works: When creating your orchestration configuration, you specify a particular modelVersion, like "2024-05-13". When this specific version is close to retirement, you will need to:
      1. Select a suitable newer model version based on your benchmarks using the SAP Note, Discovery API and/or UI.
      2. Via our harmonized API in orchestration, it is easy for you to change your configuration to a newer, specific model version.

        And only if you handle your custom defined endpoint:

      3. Patch upgrade your existing deployment to the configurationId you created newly.
    • Pros: Full control. You decide exactly which model version your application uses and when to make the change, allowing for thorough testing beforehand. This is especially important for production systems where behavioral changes in LLMs can have significant impacts.
    • Cons: More manual effort. You must actively monitor retirement dates and perform the upgrade steps yourself.

Choosing Your Strategy: Best Practices

The best strategy depends on your application's needs for stability versus automatically receiving updates.

For most production applications, especially those sensitive to potential behavioral changes in LLMs, specifying a fixed modelVersion (Manual Upgrade) has emerged as a best practice. While it requires more manual effort, it provides the necessary control and predictability. Most application owners prefer not to use the latest parameter due to the risk of unexpected behavior shifts with new LLM versions. By fixing the version, you safeguard against such changes and can plan updates proactively.

If stability and controlled changes are paramount, opt for Manual Upgrade by specifying a fixed modelVersion and plan for scheduled updates. This allows you to thoroughly test new model versions in a controlled environment before deploying them to production.

If minimizing operational overhead and automatically getting the latest model version is preferred for non-critical or exploratory applications, use Auto Upgrade with modelVersion: latest. However, remain aware that behavior might change with new versions and you need to change from model to model.

 

In Summary

As an application owner, understanding and managing the LLM model lifecycle is key to your application's longevity and reliability.

  • Regularly consult SAP Note 3437766 and/or the Discovery API (or the UI) to track model versions and retirement dates. Remember to subscribe to the SAP Note for automated updates.
  • Choose an appropriate upgrade strategy (latest for automatic updates or specifying a modelVersion for manual control) when setting up your configuration and deployment. For production scenarios, specifying a fixed modelVersion is generally recommended as a best practice.
  • If using manual upgrades, proactively change your configuration within orchestration and if custom deployment is used you need to patch/upgrade the current model version before it expires.

By staying informed and prepared, you can ensure your generative AI application continues to deliver value seamlessly, leveraging the latest innovations from the SAP’s Generative AI Hub.

We recommend keeping a close eye on the What's new section for upcoming release announcements and implementation guidance.

entry.title: Re: FPF3 - missing line items
entry.content:
Hi @fgfgfg3r43456534 

what you’re observing in FPF3 is usually standard system behaviour rather than a bug. I would advice you to check the few things below:

Each item must have a proper main/sub transaction with GL account determination (IMG à FI-CA à Postings to GL Accounting à Account Determination). Missing mapping causes items to be excluded.

Items flagged as statistical in DFKKOP are never transferred to FI instead it is only used for reporting.

Items already transferred in a previous run do not appear again in the current key.

Customizing or active BAdIs for example events 1120/1130 may exclude items.

Here is what I suggest you consider:

First, run FPG1/FPG2 in test mode with the affected document and check the transfer log.

Then, compare the missing line’s main or sub with one that is transferred correctly.

Finally, verify DFKKOP flags and GL determination in FQZ1/FQZ2.

This should help you pinpoint why the account ending in 12 is excluded from the reconciliation key.

You can consult https://help.sap.com/docs/ for more help.

SAP Note 1445092 and 2652284 will also provide some insights.

 

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Customer Public Dimension with wrong spatial data
entry.content:
Hi @egil63 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

The error you are seeing usually means that some designated records in your CUSTOMER dimension have some mismatches.

It is highly likely that you have empty values or the values do not correspond to what is expected from your system for mapping. For example, spatial data like country codes or geo-coordinates for it to function. Even though all six customers are from Taiwan and the ISO code "TW" is mapped, here are some likely causes and solutions you may consider:

First, if one or more of your customers have a blank value in the CUSTOMER field, those records will either be rejected or will cause errors. Please note that in SAP Analytics Cloud and similar modelling tools, all required dimension fields must have a value.

To solve this, I suggest you check your data source and ensure there are no blanks or nulls in the CUSTOMER dimension columns.

Second, it is good practice to maintain a "# unassigned" or "Unknown" value in your CUSTOMER dimension master data for cases where your customer value is missing. But you must also make sure that, during your data transformation or wrangling, all of the empty or null values are explicitly mapped to this unassigned code.

To solve that, ensure that in your data import/transformation (ETL) process, you configure a rule to replace empty CUSTOMER fields with "#", "Unknown", or another placeholder defined in your predefined dimension.

Third, if your fact table also called the main data table has CUSTOMER values that does not exist in the CUSTOMER dimension table, an example is, a typo or missing entry, these rows will appear blank or throw an error on validation.

A solution to this will be to ensure all CUSTOMER keys in transactional data are present in your dimension table and that there are no mismatches.

Finally, for models using spatial data, the CUSTOMER or related fields might be expected to have proper geo-coordinates or standard codes. Even if "TW" is mapped, check that the spatial data requirements are fully met for all records

To summarize, here are the steps mentioned above:

First, review your CUSTOMER master data for blanks or incorrect values

Then, add a placeholder value for unknown/null customers and ensure ETL maps empty entries to this value.

Thereafter, make sure all CUSTOMER keys in transactional data have a match in the dimension table.

Finally, double-check any geo/spatial data requirements your tool has for the CUSTOMER dimension.

If you check these points and correct the data, the issue should be resolved.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Business partner 2288 already existsMessage no. R1286
entry.content:
Hello community

Business Scenario
During the ECC to SAP ERP 6.0 EHP8 conversion project, we are executing the Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI) activities.

Both Customers and Vendors have been historically maintained with the same external number range (ZZ: 0000000001 – 0000009999).
The same external number range has also been defined for Business Partners (ZZ: 0000000001 – 0000009999) 

In the direction BP ↔ Customer/Vendor, the mapping was configured so that identical numbers should be used across BP, Customer, and Vendor.

Current Issue
The CVI Cockpit (CVI_COCKPIT) was executed successfully for Vendors.

For Vendor 2288, a Business Partner 2288 was created and linked (entry exists in table CVI_VEND_LINK).

However, when attempting to synchronize Customers with the same number (2288), the system raises the following errors:

Business partner 2288 already exists

Message no. R1286

When trying to extend the existing BP manually in transaction BP with the Customer role (FLCU00), the system does not allow saving because the Customer key already exists in KNA1/KNB1.

The following error is issued:
Customer data was not saved due to error CVI_MAPPING 042; see long text

Message no. CVI_BDT_ADAPTER050

Problem Statement


Due to the identical number ranges, when trying to synchronize Customers, the system fails because the BP number already exists and is linked to the Vendor.

Manual maintenance in BP is also blocked, as the Customer number already exists in KNA1/KNB1.

How can we solve this problem?

 

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Comprehensive Overview “RISE With SAP “Dashboard within SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Comprehensive Overview “RISE With SAP “Dashboard within SAP Cloud ALM

The "RISE with SAP" Dashboard with SAP Cloud ALM is a strategic tool designed to support SAP customers on their cloud transformation journey, focusing on maintaining a clean core and ensuring cloud compliance and upgrade readiness.

Purpose and Benefits:

  • Supports transition to SAP S/4HANA Cloud with a focus on minimizing technical debt.
  • Enables faster upgrades and continuous innovation.
  • Improves system performance, reliability, and flexibility.
  • Leverages cloud-based tools like SAP BTP for added functionalities without modifying the core.

Clean Core Approach:

  • Emphasizes reducing customizations and obsolete code.
  • Facilitates easier upgrades, better integration, and system agility.
  • Promotes using cloud tools for extensions rather than core modifications.

Tools and Dashboards:

  • SAP Cloud ALM supports the Clean Core approach by providing dashboards that monitor compliance across different dimensions:
    • System View Dashboard: Provides an overview of system compliance, covering SAP S/4HANA systems in various environments (production, test, development). It tracks data collection status and supports SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.
    • Operation View Dashboard: Offers operational insights, KPIs, and ratings related to system health and compliance on the operational side.
    • Executive Dashboard (Upcoming): Intended for executive-level summaries and strategic decision-making.

Clean Core Dimensions Covered:

  • Extensibility
  • Operations
  • Integrations
  • Data
  • Business Processes

Why SAP Cloud ALM supports the adoption of clean core

Capabilities of” RISE with SAP “ Dashboard

entry.title: Re: Übermittlung statistische Kennzahl in Personalkostenp...
entry.content:
Hi @UlrikeEscherich 

Danke für die Frage.

Bei der Personalkostenplanung in SAP, insbesondere beim Thema statistische Kennzahlen wie FTE, gibt es einige wichtige Punkte zu beachten:

Es ist wichtig zu wissen, dass die Kennzahl zum Beispiel FTE im Customizing nicht nur angelegt muss, sondern sie muss auch korrekt mit den Kostenarten verknüpft sein, damit sie im Kostenplanungslauf berücksichtigt wird.

Die zugrundeliegenden Daten sollten im System gepflegt sein zum Beispiel über Infotypen oder Schnittstellen aus HR-Systemen, sonst werden die Werte im Planungslauf nicht angezeigt.

Der Planungslauf muss auch so eingestellt sein, dass neben Primärkosten auch die statistische Kennzahlen mit-geplant und an das Controlling übergeben werden. Dafür gibt es in der Personalkostenplanung spezielle Einstellungen.

Leider ist die Dokumentation zu diesem Thema häufig knapp. Ein guter Startpunkt sind SAP-Hilfen zu Personalkostenplanung und Steuerung von Kennzahlen, sowie Support- oder Beratungsangebote.

Mein Tipp wäre, Prüfen Sie im Customizing nochmals, ob alle Verbindungen zwischen Kostenarten und statistischen Kennzahlen komplett sind und ob der Kostenplanungslauf für statistische Daten richtig eingestellt ist. Ebenso lohnt sich ein Blick, ob im laufenden Planungsprozess die FTE-Daten korrekt bereitgestellt werden. Falls möglich, testen Sie mit einfachen Beispielwerten, um das Verhalten nachzuvollziehen.

Ich hoffe das hilft weiter.

Beste Grüsse

Chris

entry.title: Re: Payroll India - Gross Up Tax Calculation
entry.content:
Hi @Akash_Sharma11o7 

Regarding your requirement, let me walk you through possible scenarios.

First, you will need to create a custom Personnel Calculation Rule that helps you Identifies these specific wage types,

Then, one that calculates the tax based on the applicable higher tax slab rate, which is similar to how tax slabs are handled in country-specific payroll schemas,

One that generates corresponding wage types representing the advance tax payment and

Finally, one that includes these wage types as taxable amounts in payroll.

Please note that standard SAP does not offer a turnkey PCR for this scenario, so you will likely need to build logic that queries tax slab rates per employee which is potentially done via custom tables or functions and applies these dynamically.

I recommend reviewing the standard payroll tax functions like INTAX for reference and ensuring your PCR integrates at the right point in the payroll schema to affect net calculation correctly.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

3444595 - Employee tax is not calculated in an off-cycle payment

entry.title: Re: Properties and Action Feature layer Configuration in...
entry.content:
Hello @rafael_umeda 

Hi Rafael,

Yes, your understanding is accurate. In SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM), the Properties section of the feature layer configuration links the GIS attributes from your ArcGIS feature layer to the object cell fields shown in the mobile app.

For example:

{

  "ID": "{objectid}",

  "Title": "{state_name}",

  "HeadlineText": "{state_abbr}",

  "Subhead": "{pop2023}"

}

This means that when a user taps on a feature in the map, such as a state polygon, SSAM will display those properties in the object cell details (ID, Title, Headline, Subhead) in the map callout.

Action configuration varies, allowing you to specify what occurs when the user interacts with that feature. For instance, you can set up actions such as

  • Navigate to a Work Order or Notification related to the feature.
  • Launch another app page (e.g., equipment details).
  • Trigger a workflow or custom extension (via Rule or Action binding).

In brief:

  • Properties → define which GIS attributes are shown in the SSAM map popup/object cell.
  • Actions → define what the user can do with that feature (open details, start work, navigate, custom script).

Refer to the SAP documentation below, and let me know if you need further information

  • SAP Help – Configuring Your Map Settings in SSAM

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP EWM Podcast - Episode 24 - Is It Art or Can It Be Thrown Away? Archiving in SAP EWM!
entry.content:
SAP EWM Podcast - Episode 24 - Is It Art or Can It Be Thrown Away? Archiving in SAP EWM!

In the world of warehouse management, efficiency and performance are paramount. Yet, one topic often remains in the shadows of project planning and daily operations: archiving in SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). While tidying up may not be anyone’s favorite task—whether at home or in IT—it’s essential for maintaining a clean, performant, and future-proof SAP system.

This blog post explores the importance of archiving in SAP EWM, what data should be archived or deleted, and how it ties into broader concepts like Clean Core and compliance.

You can listen to the podcast episodes in English and in German on Spotify, Amazon Music, Apple Podcasts or Sway! Enjoy!

Why Archiving Matters in SAP Systems

Archiving isn’t just about freeing up space—it’s a strategic necessity. Here are the key reasons to regularly clean up your SAP system:

  • Performance Optimization: Smaller database tables mean faster queries, shorter load times, and improved response times in daily operations.
  • Cost Efficiency: SAP HANA uses RAM-based storage, which is significantly more expensive than traditional disk storage. Reducing data volume can lower costs, especially during migrations to S/4HANA.
  • Clean Core Alignment: A lean system is easier to maintain and upgrade. Archiving supports the Clean Core principle by minimizing unnecessary data and avoiding workarounds that complicate system architecture.

Archiving vs. Deletion: What’s the Difference?

When tidying up, it’s crucial to distinguish between archiving and deletion:

  • Archiving: Data is removed from the operational system but retained in an audit-proof format.
  • Deletion: Data is permanently removed and must be carefully considered, especially in regulated environments.

Regular cleanup jobs are essential for stable SAP EWM operations. Tools like the Database Cockpit (DBA_COCKPIT) or DB02 help identify large tables, such as:

  • BALHDR, BALDAT – Application Logs
  • CDHDR, CDPOS – Change Documents
  • PPFTTRIGG – PPF Actions
  • Various /SCWM/ and /SCDL/ tables in the EWM domain

Check large tables in the SAP system using transaction DB02

 

Guidance and Tools for Cleanup

SAP provides valuable resources to support cleanup efforts. The Operations Guide for SAP S/4HANA, particularly the EWM chapter, outlines cleanup reports and their recommended scheduling. These reports help manage:

  • Application Logs
  • Change Documents
  • PPF Actions
  • Spool Requests
  • Alerts

Be cautious with logging settings, especially for change documents in EWM. Granular settings can lead to massive data volumes, impacting both database size and user performance.

Example of EWM related clean up tasks described in the operations guide

 

Legal and Compliance Considerations

Archiving isn’t just technical—it’s also legal. In Germany, for example, the Tax Code and Commercial Code mandate retention of bookkeeping-relevant data for ten years. Meanwhile, data protection regulations like the EU GDPR require that personal data be stored only as long as necessary.

SAP’s Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) provides tools to manage retention policies and ensure compliance. While this blog doesn’t offer legal advice, it’s important to understand the regulatory framework surrounding data retention.

How Archiving Works in SAP

The SAP archiving process follows a structured approach:

  1. Eligibility Check: The system verifies whether a document is complete and whether all related documents are also archived.
  2. Archive File Creation: Eligible data is written into archive files, which are stored on cost-effective media—often cloud-based solutions like OpenText.

In EWM, for example, archiving warehouse tasks requires that referenced delivery documents are completed. This ensures data integrity and proper sequencing.

Understanding Archive Info Structures

Once data is archived, it must remain accessible for audits or operational needs. This is where archive info structures come into play.

  • These structures are stored in database tables and contain key fields of the archived SAP objects.
  • For example, in warehouse task archiving, fields like warehouse number, task number, item, and a unique archive file identifier are included.
  • Additional fields—such as warehouse order number or storage bin—can be added based on project-specific requirements.
  • A special field called offset indicates the exact location of the object within the archive file, similar to a page number in a book.

Example of archive info structure for warehouse task archiving

 

To access archived data, SAP provides the transaction SARE , which allows users to search and display archived objects across applications. For EWM-specific data, archived documents can often be viewed directly via the SAP EWM warehouse management monitor or standard display transactions.

Once data is successfully archived, it can be deleted from the database. SAP reads the archive file, identifies the original documents, and removes them from the operational system—achieving the goal of a lean and performant database.

SAP ILM: Lifecycle Management and Compliance

SAP Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) extends traditional archiving with features that support:

  • GDPR compliance
  • Data blocking and deletion rules
  • Lifecycle management for both structured and unstructured data

ILM enables organizations to define policies for when data should be blocked, archived, or deleted—especially important for customer or business partner data. It’s available in SAP ERP and S/4HANA as a standard business function, with no additional licensing costs.

Archiving in SAP EWM: Objects and Timing

SAP EWM includes archiving objects for all major business processes, accessible via transaction SARA. These include:

  • Deliveries
  • Warehouse tasks and orders
  • Handling units
  • Physical inventory documents
  • Value-added service documents
  • Waves
  • Transport unit activities
  • MFS telegrams

Example of SAP EWM Archiving Object Value Added Service Order

 

Legal Relevance and Residence Time

Before archiving, organizations must assess:

  • Which data is legally relevant?
    Often, ERP documents like deliveries or material documents are subject to retention laws.

  • When should data be archived?
    This is defined by the residence time—the period data remains in the system after process completion.

SAP provides guidance through SAP note 2378179

  • Warehouse tasks: ~3 months
  • Deliveries: ~6 months

Residence time can also be influenced by internal compliance policies or SLA agreements. For deliveries, EWM offers dedicated customizing options; for other objects, residence time is set during archiving via SARA.

Custom Developments and Archiving Strategy

Custom developments must be considered in any archiving strategy. For custom tables or extensions, developers should plan from the start how data will be removed—either via deletion jobs or custom archiving objects.

Preparing for Migration to S/4HANA EWM

Migrating from SCM-EWM to S/4HANA-EWM is a functional migration, not a technical system conversion. This means:

  • Old data cannot be transferred by default and must be archived beforehand.
  • Master data structures change, affecting the display of archived documents in the new system.

Recommended Approach

  • Archive relevant data before migration.
  • Start fresh in the new system.
  • Use a legacy system or archive viewer to access old documents if needed.

For advanced scenarios, archived files can be converted to be compatible with S/4HANA EWM. This involves reading old archive files, adjusting changed data, and writing new archive files for the target system—a process supported by SAP’s Center of Expertise.

Monitoring and Validation Tools

To ensure your EWM system is properly set up for archiving, SAP offers:

  • The SAP Operations Guide with detailed archiving instructions.
  • EarlyWatch Reports with EWM-specific checks:
    • Are recommended background jobs scheduled?
    • Is archiving correctly configured for EWM objects?

These reports also provide broader insights into system health and performance.

Conclusion: Make Archiving a Priority

Archiving is not just a technical necessity—it’s a strategic enabler for SAP EWM systems. It ensures:

  • System performance and stability
  • Compliance with legal and internal policies
  • Smooth upgrades and migrations

By integrating archiving into your system lifecycle and project planning, you lay the foundation for a clean, efficient, and future-ready SAP EWM environment.

Please visit our SAP EWM Podcast Landing Page with all Episodes, Blog Posts and Podcast Notes!

entry.title: Re: GRC - Não existe XML no centro trabalho
entry.content:
Hello @AmberlyP 

The error “no XML exists in the work center; no detail available” usually means that the NF-e XML was not correctly stored in GRC or is not available in the distribution queue. Even though the history log shows creation and validation as successful, a synchronization issue can occur between NF-e creation and the validation/distribution step.

How to begin the analysis:

Check the NF-e message monitor in GRC – Use the NF-e Outbound Message Monitor app/transaction to confirm whether the XML was actually generated and stored.

Check the distribution queue – See if the NF-e is listed for distribution or stuck with an inconsistent status.

Review application logs – In GRC, look at the Application Logs for the NF-e to see if there was a failure when generating the XML.

Reprocess the document – Often, restarting the “Create NF-e” step or manually triggering distribution resolves the issue, as long as there are no fiscal blocks.

Validate configuration – Make sure the work center and environment are configured to store and display XMLs (a common cause of this message).

Practical tip below

  • Try to regenerate the XML in GRC.
  • If the error persists, check the technical logs and open a support case with the NF-e key and error logs (SAP may require a Note or correction).

SAP Documentations

  • SAP Help – SAP Document Compliance, Brazil NF-e
  • 2941031 - NF-e Technical Note 2024.001 Troubleshooting Guide

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Boosting HR Data Quality in SuccessFactors: The Three Pillars for Driving Employee Central Value
entry.content:
In today’s digital workplace, HR data is more than a set of records — it’s the foundation for every payroll run, workforce report, and talent decision. When that foundation is shaky, the ripple effects are immediate and costly: delayed processes, bad analytics, compliance risks, and loss of executive trust.

At SAP SuccessFactors, we see the strongest results when customers approach data quality as an ongoing discipline, not just an afterthought. In Employee Central, this discipline can be framed around three pillars — each supported by embedded tools and best practices.

Pillar 1: Ensure Valid Configuration

The quality of your data starts with the quality of your configuration. A poorly designed rule or unchecked setting can silently introduce errors that multiply over time.

 Key enablers in Employee Central:

  • Business Rule Scenarios – Replace outdated “basic” rule setup with guided, scenario-based creation that reduces misconfigurations, enforces supported objects, and makes it easier to see where each rule is used.
  • Configuration Validations – Built-in guardrails in the Business Configuration UI and Foundation Objects to prevent risky changes (e.g., making business keys mandatory, external codes of Foundation Objects read-only).
  • Check Tool – Over 80 automated checks for configuration and data consistency, helping you resolve issues before they surface in production.
  • Diagnostic Tool – Trace the exact workflow or employee data change, see which business rules triggered, who approved, and what happened behind the scenes - invaluable for troubleshooting.

When these controls are in place, you start from a position of stability, rather than firefighting downstream issues.

 

Pillar 2: Enforce Valid Master Data

Even with perfect configuration, data quality can break down at the point of entry if there are no safeguards. This pillar is about guiding HR teams, managers, and employees to enter data correctly the first time.

 Practical examples in Employee Central:

  • Built-in Validations – Stop users from deleting key objects still in use, entering impossible dates of birth, or saving malformed email addresses.
  • Field Criteria & Associations – Filter selections dynamically (e.g., only show cost centres valid for the chosen legal entity) to avoid mismatches.
  • Conditional Defaulting – Automatically populate values like pay group or probation period based on complex criteria, reducing manual input.
  • Business Rules with Messages – Trigger warnings, errors, or informational messages in real time to prevent incorrect data saves.
  • Four-Eyes Principle in Workflows – Ensure no one approves their own requests, supporting compliance and audit integrity.
  • Alerts & Notifications – Proactively flag upcoming events (work permit expiry, end of contract, probation period) so action is taken before deadlines occur.
  • Configurable Hire Templates – Tailor the hire process to role, country, or employment type, reducing irrelevant fields and errors.

By embedding these measures, organisations move from reactive clean-up to preventative design — a far more sustainable approach.

 

Pillar 3: Identify & Cleanse Master Data

No system is immune to errors. The third pillar is about detecting and correcting issues quickly before they cause broader disruption.

 Tools to support cleansing in Employee Central:

  • Admin Alerts – Real-time notifications for data inconsistencies, stalled workflows, or invalid role assignments.
  • Data Check Tool – Over 40 checks for employee records, from missing work permit details to duplicate emergency contacts or overlapping dependent timelines.
  • Quick Fixes – In certain cases, the system can auto-correct issues found by checks, turning a multi-hour cleanup into a one-click action.

Proactive monitoring here not only protects daily operations but also keeps analytics, reporting, and AI training datasets trustworthy.

 

From Reactive to Proactive Data Quality

The organisations that extract the most value from Employee Central treat data quality as a living process — continuously monitored, refined, and embedded into both system design and daily HR operations.

It’s not about running a “data cleanup project” once a year. It’s about having guardrails at configuration time, smart validations at data entry, and powerful diagnostics and alerts for when something does go wrong. This holistic approach turns HR data into a genuine business asset — reliable, compliant, and ready to power strategic decisions.

 

Watch our recent webinar and access the slides for more information:

Webinar Recording & slides:  Boosting HR Data Quality: 3 Pillars for Driving Employee Central Business Value

 

Further Resources
SAP provides extensive guidance, release updates, and best practices to help you adopt these capabilities, from Business Rule Scenario migration blogs to Check Tool documentation. Regularly reviewing these resources, and building them into your governance model,  ensures that your data quality program evolves alongside your business.

  • IDP - EmployeeCentral - Optimizing Business Rules For Specific Scenarios
  • Centralized Services in Employee Central | SAP Help Portal
  • Using the Check Tool to Solve Issues | SAP Help Portal
  • Defining Alert Triggering Rules | SAP Help Portal

 

#pathtosuccess #employeecentral #dataquality

entry.title: Creating an SSI Wallet for an Issuer
entry.content:
SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification service enables organizations to manage and verify digital identities securely. While the Holder Wallet is primarily used to receive and present verifiable credentials, it can be extended to issue verifiable credentials as well. This extension allows organizations to act as credential issuers, providing trusted digital proofs of identity, product attributes, and more.

This article explains how a wallet can be created with the capability to issue Verifiable Credentials (VCs) using SAP’s Administration Dashboard or API.

An issuer wallet requires the following key components to function properly:

  1. Signing Key: The issuer wallet must include a specific signing key dedicated to signing Verifiable Credentials (VCs). This key is of the type `assertionMethod` and is referenced within the `didDocument` to enable secure and verifiable credential issuance.
  2. Issuer Service Endpoint: The `didDocument` must specify an issuer-specific service endpoint. This endpoint, of type `IssuerService`, enables interaction with the issuer's services, facilitating seamless communication between the issuer and credential holders (e.g. requesting verifiable credentials).
  3. Metadata Endpoint: A metadata endpoint must be provided. This service contains public issuer information, including a list of credential types the issuer is authorized and willing to issue for eligible holders.

Create an Identity with Issuer Functionality

  • Create a new identity: Select the option to create a new pre-configured identity.
  • During the configuration process, ensure the protocols `dcp-holder` and `dcp-issuer` are selected. The `dcp-issuer` configuration will prepare the wallet for credential issuance:
    • Generates the required signing key of type `assertionMethod`, which is used for signing Verifiable Credentials.
    • Adds the issuer-specific service endpoint (type: `IssuerService`) to the `didDocument`, facilitating issuer-related interactions.
    • Creates an empty metadata endpoint, which can later be configured to host public metadata about the issuer, such as supported credential types and other issuer-related information.

An issuer identity can be created via the API by specifying the dcp-holder and dcp-issuer protocols in the request payload.

POST {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "payload": {
    "bootstrap": {
      "description": "issuer",
      "name": "m-x issuer
     }
}

Adding a Revocation List

A revocation list is necessary to invalidate credentials when they become obsolete or compromised.

Using the Administration Dashboard:

  • Navigate to Identity section.
  • Enable Revocation Support and define the revocation mechanism.

Using the API:

Create a revocation list with:

POST {srv_url}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities/{Id}/revocationLists
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "payload": {
    "create": {
      "type": "StatusList2021",
      "name": "List 1",
      "description": "Revocation list 1",
      "length": 2097152
    }
  }
}

 

Adding the Issuer Configuration

The credential types that the issuer is willing to issue need to be specified. Additionally, you can determine whether credential requests are processed automatically or manually. For automatic processing, you can specify whether all matching credentials or only the latest credential should be provided to the holder. 

Using the Administration Dashboard:

  • Navigate to Identity section.
  • Press the button Issuer Configuration and maintain the credential types.

In the second step, you need to configure the issuer details. Access the issuer configuration by clicking the corresponding button on the company identity screen. To add a new issuer configuration for the selected company identity, select both the credential type and the approval mode. There are three ways an issuer can respond to credential requests when the requested credential has already been issued. With this configuration, you can determine whether credential requests are processed automatically or manually. For automatic processing, you also have the option to specify whether all matching credentials or only the latest credential should be issued to the holder. Additionally, you can add a schema to further define the credential structure. Make sure to save your changes to apply the new issuer configuration.

 

Using the API:

Update the issuer configuration with:

PATCH {div_ srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities/{id}/issuerConfigurations/{id}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "addCredentialTypes": [
  {
    "name": "CompanyCredential",
    "approvalMode": "all_vc",
    "schema": "{schema url}"
  }]
}

 

Conclusion

With these configurations in place, the wallet is now fully equipped to act as a credential issuer. Organizations leveraging SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification can now issue verifiable credentials, such as:

  • Manufacturing-X Credentials, such as membership credentials for consortium participation.
  • Digital Product Passports (DPP)
  • Product Carbon Footprint (PCF) Certificates for sustainability verification.

This extension empowers organizations to participate in a trusted digital identity ecosystem.

Next step: 

Configure the Trust List in a Decentralized Identity Verification Wallet

Read more

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Company identity documentation
  • API documentation in detail

entry.title: How to perform a successful Carve-Out in SAP ECC and S/4HANA – Update and New Trends 2025 (Part I)
entry.content:
It has been four years since I published my original five-part series on SAP Carve-Outs - covering basic topics from what a carve out is (Part I), data migration (Part II) and technical orchestration (Part III) to process and analytics considerations (Part IV) and S/4HANA value creation (Part V).

Time for a look back on what has changed since then with new trends for SAP Carve-Outs and Divestiture Projects in business and technology.

The good news is: The core principles and methods outlined in those earlier posts remain as relevant today as they were then.

However, the past four years have brought notable shifts in both business dynamics and technology landscapes, reshaping how carve-out projects must be planned, managed, and executed. In many cases, these changes have introduced greater complexity, requiring organizations to adapt their strategies to ensure success.

From our recent project experience and industry observations, two main drivers stand out:

  1. More complex M&A scenarios – including multi-entity, multi-source, and joint-venture carve-outs, often with heightened compliance and harmonization requirements.
  2. Technology disruption – particularly the accelerated move to the cloud and the looming SAP ECC end-of-maintenance deadlines (2027, or 2030 with costly extended maintenance under SAP RISE).

In this update, I will explore these emerging trends from two perspectives:

Business & M&A Scenario-Driven Trends (Part I):

  • Harmonization of processes and structures during the carve-out to reduce operational complexity post-transition.
  • Multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs that combine data from different systems into a consolidated environment.
  • Enhanced compliance and legal alignment to address stricter regulatory and contractual requirements.
  • Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go-live to keep operations running seamlessly and without any business disruption

Technology-Driven Trends (Part II):

  • Move to cloud – whether via hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud) in private hosting, or through SAP RISE and GROW with SAP offerings.
  • Expanded functional and integration scope – including SAP modules, third-party systems (Salesforce, Ariba, IBP, EDI), and rebuilt analytics landscapes.
  • Combined carve-out and S/4HANA transformation to deliver a modern, value-enhanced system to the buyer.
  • Custom code carve-out and clean-core modernization to simplify future operations and reduce technical debt.

Both parts of this post build on the foundation of the original series, now enriched with current project examples and the latest industry best practices - offering a forward-looking view of what it takes to execute a successful carve-out in 2025 and beyond.

 

Business and M&A Scenario–Driven Trends in Modern SAP Carve-Outs

1. Harmonization of Processes and Structures

In recent years, we have seen a growing emphasis on harmonizing processes and organizational structures during carve-outs – especially to reduce operational complexity after the transition. This is particularly common among private equity buyers, who aim to simplify process variants, adopt industry best practices over heavy customization, and standardize reporting structures across multiple acquisitions. Two main approaches are used:

Option 1: Greenfield Implementation in the Public Cloud

Some buyers opt for a brand-new SAP system - often in an SAP GROW public cloud environment - built entirely on standardized, industry best-practice processes.

  • Advantages: Fast to implement, provides a clean slate, and allows extensions via SAP BTP without burdening the core system.
  • Caveats:
    • Historic data is typically lost, requiring separate archival for audit or business purposes.
    • The “big bang” cutover into entirely new processes can disrupt business operations without strong change management.

This approach is best suited for asset deals or acquisitions of smaller, less complex entities.

Option 2: Selective Data Transition (SDT)

With the right Transformation Software, SDT enables you to migrate only selected data while simultaneously transforming processes, configurations, and structures. For example, in a carve-out involving multiple company codes from a highly integrated environment, intercompany relationships may need to be converted into customer-vendor-structures - requiring both process reconfiguration and master/transactional data transformation.

SDT also allows:

  • Changing charts of accounts, profit/cost centers, plants, and org structures.
  • Transforming open and historical transactional data to match new processes.
  • Maintaining a continuity of historical data in the new environment.

Trade-offs: SDT is more complex, typically requiring 6-12 months for high-complexity projects and demanding greater involvement from both IT and business teams.

We have seen SDT increasingly used in share deals, spin-offs, and large-scale asset divestitures with significant process complexity.

 

2. Multi-Source & Joint-Venture Carve-Outs

Another fast-growing trend involves multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs, where data from multiple ERP systems must be consolidated into one new environment.

Typical scenarios:

  • Multi-source carve-out: Extracting data from several ERP systems (ECC, S/4HANA, or both) within the same organization, often during ongoing SAP S/4HANA transformation projects.
  • Joint-venture setup: Merging data and processes from multiple partners into a shared system.

Challenges include:

  • Harmonizing master data, processes, charts of accounts, and org structures – including historic transactional data.
  • Managing licensing and data visibility between different corporate owners.
  • Separating and rebuilding formerly shared subsystems or third-party integrations.

Given their complexity, these projects nearly always use SDT combined with system merge methodologies, cross-system harmonization, and automation for plant or unit reallocation - while ensuring strict data access controls between Joint-Venture partners.

Additionally, these projects require a significant engagement from SAP specialists to adjust and reshape processes, harmonize data and organizaional structures, properly adjust interfaces to external or cloud-based systems, and enhance data analytics and reporting. Due to the variety of skill sets needed and the urgency in a carve-out project, the setup usually requires engaging with a specialized System Integrator (SI) early in the project planning phase to ensure these topics are successfully covered.

 

3. Enhanced Compliance & Legal Alignment

Stricter regulations and geopolitical constraints now significantly influence carve-out planning and execution.

Examples include:

  • GDPR for companies doing business in EU-countries
  • Industry-specific requirements (e.g., regulated industries like Utilities, Aerospace & Defense).
  • Data sovereignty laws such as China’s DSL, CSL, and PIPL, which can require a separate, localized SAP system, to protect your global business data by keeping it separate.

Implications:

  • Migrate only approved data subsets, particularly personal data.
  • Ensure full audit documentation of extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Include technical safeguards such as log tracing, reversible deletions, and cutover checks.

Modern SDT Software products - like cbs ET Enterprise Transformer - already offer audit-grade logging for these processes, making compliance easier to prove post-project.

 

Vendor landscape Note:

In the context of the SDT approach, it is worth noting that only four vendors worldwide currently provide both the specialized SDT software and the associated service capabilities needed for complex carve-out scenarios. All are members of the SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement Program and typically collaborate with other system integrators (SI) to cover the full range of services required.

At present, only one of these vendors is able to deliver the complete end-to-end service portfolio independently - an advantage that means fewer communication gaps, with consultants who understand the full scope of services and the role of SDT in the project, rather than working in isolated silos.

Given the sustained market demand for SDT-based initiatives - including both carve-outs and broader SAP S/4HANA transformation projects - delivery capacity can become a bottleneck. To mitigate this risk, organizations should secure delivery slots as early as possible, ideally before the transaction is finalized and the Transition Services Agreement (TSA) is signed, to ensure the resource availability and alignment with agreed project timelines.

 

4. Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go/live

A successful carve-out is not just about getting the technical cutover right - it’s equally about ensuring the carved-out organization can operate smoothly from day one. One of the most significant risks during these projects is operational disruption, which both buyer and seller are highly motivated to avoid before, during, and after the system handover. Maintaining stable business operations has increasingly become therefore a central project goal.

Change Management and Training

Beyond ensuring clean, accurate data in the new system, it is critical to prepare the business workforce for changes to their daily processes and routines. This requires structured change management and targeted training in all areas where processes are being redesigned or where new roles and responsibilities are introduced. This becomes even more important when moving to more standardized, harmonized processes - often with fewer customization and a leaner user interface than in the previous environment.

In such cases, acceptance grows when users understand the why behind the change and are given the tools and guidance to confidently perform their work in the new system. Proper preparation minimizes post–go-live disruption and supports long-term adoption.

Application Management Services (AMS)

In recent years, we have seen a strong trend toward integrating AMS into carve-out project scope from the outset. This is particularly relevant when:

  • The carved-out entity lacks internal SAP expertise after organizational changes or downsizing post-transaction.
  • The seller’s IT services under the TSA come at a premium, and the buyer seeks a faster, more cost-effective transition away from them.
  • The buyer needs a bridging solution until a new internal IT team is in place.

Some AMS providers even offer fractional consulting for small-scale enhancements and process improvements after go-live, adding flexibility during the stabilization phase.

Choosing a provider who delivers AMS as part of a comprehensive business transformation has clear advantages, as they understand carve-out–specific requirements such as altered team responsibilities, new support structures, and heightened service continuity needs.

For smaller and mid-sized organizations, SAP’s M&A Ambassador Program can be a valuable option, particularly for PE-driven carve-outs. It equips these projects with expert partner frameworks to manage both the initial deployment and post-go-live stabilization. Unfortunately, this program does not include any provider with SDT capabilities.

Recommendation: Define AMS scope and contracts early - including infrastructure operations, interface monitoring, patching, SLA targets, and knowledge handover - so that post-go-live operations run as smoothly as the cutover itself.

 

Summary of Part I and Key Takeaways

Over the past years, my team and I have seen, and experienced with our customers, that carve-outs in 2025 are no longer purely IT-driven exercises.They are strategic business transformations requiring early leadership engagement and precise planning.

On the business side, the key success factors are:

  • Early preparation: Business readiness and TSA alignment before signing prevent costly delays.
  • Selective Data Transition (SDT) as a game changer: Enabling selective migration and process harmonization with minimal disruption; early partner selection is crucial given limited global capacity.
  • Integrated service delivery: One provider delivering end-to-end reduces communication gaps and ensures holistic understanding.
  • Business continuity protection: Early investment in process mapping, change management, and training ensures smoother cutovers.
  • Built-in stabilization: Integrating AMS from the onset speeds post–go-live recovery.
  • Organizational change management: Early engagement drives faster adoption and productivity.

For the technical delivery models, toolsets, and SDT-related innovations shaping carve-outs in 2025 and beyond, see Part II of this Update 2025 post.

If you’d like to discuss your own carve-out scenario, feel free to contact me directly. @Lorenz_Praefcke2

entry.title: Re: RSA1 - Some Objects Cannot be edited
entry.content:
Hello @Kevin06 

The reason you cannot edit these BW objects in DEV is that the original system of the objects is QA, since they were created there. If the original system isn't DEV, the change/edit mode in DEV will always be disabled. You can confirm this in SE03 → Display Object Directory Entry.

The error “Object Cube XXXX is generated and cannot be transported” also indicates that you attempted to collect a generated/runtime artefact (such as tables or programmes) instead of the design-time object. Only the design object Info Cube, DSO/ADSO, Transformation, DTP) should be collected in RSA1 → Transport Connection.

How to resolve this issue

  • Follow Best practice: Recreate or import the objects into DEV to ensure DEV regains ownership. Then transport correctly from DEV to QA and eventually to PROD..
  • Alternative option: Use SE03 to change the Object Directory Entry and reassign the original system ownership back to DEV. This requires a repair task and should only be performed under Basis/transport governance.

SAP Note 125445 – BW objects in transport system

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Configure the Trust List in a Decentralized Identity Verification Wallet
entry.content:
SSI wallets have revolutionized the way users manage and present Verifiable Credentials (VCs) and Verifiable Presentations (VPs). However, these interactions often lack a formalized trust framework guiding which issuers are considered trustworthy.

A trust configuration is a declarative policy, defining trusted entities (issuers). This configuration typically includes:

  • Trusted issuers' decentralized identifiers (DIDs)
  • (Optional) Accepted credential types

If a trust configuration includes specific credential types, only those types from that issuer are trusted; if no types are specified, all credentials from the issuer are trusted. When a VC is presented for verification, DIV checks this list to determine whether the credential can be trusted based on the issuer and the credential type. This process ensures that only credentials from recognized and trusted issuers are accepted.

In the following figure, you can see that the verified verifiable credential is valid; however, the trusted issuer is not included in the trust list. 

The trust list within the wallet serves a dual purpose. Apart from guiding verifiers during the validation of Verifiable Credentials and Presentations, it is also actively used by holders to manage interactions with issuers - specifically when sending credential requests or accepting credential offers.

When a holder wants to send a credential request to an issuer, the trust list allows them to select from the credential types supported by that issuer. This ensures that requests are aligned with what the issuer can provide, simplifying the credential issuance process.

For credential offers received from issuers, the trust list defines how these offers are handled:

  • Automatic Processing: If the holder configures the trust list to process offers automatically, receiving a credential offer will immediately trigger an automatic credential request back to the issuer, streamlining the issuance without manual intervention.
  • Manual Processing: Alternatively, if manual processing is selected, credential offers are stored, allowing the holder to review incoming offers at their convenience. The holder can then decide which offers to accept by explicitly sending credential requests, adding a layer of user control and consent before credential issuance.

This flexible approach empowers holders to customize their interaction flow with trusted issuers - balancing automation for convenience and manual oversight.

 

How to Configure the Trust List in Decentralized Identity Verification

To extend your Decentralized Identity Verification wallet with trust configuration for issuers, follow these steps:

  1. Open the Trust Issuer Section
  2. Add a Trusted Issuer: Click the Add button to create a new trusted issuer entry.
  3. Enter Issuer Details:
    1. Issuer DID: Input the decentralized identifier (DID) of the issuer you want to trust.
    2. Select Application: Choose the relevant application for this trust relationship.
    3. Choose Credential Types: Select from the list of credential types that the issuer supports. These types are fetched from the issuer’s metadata endpoint.
    4. Set Processing Mode: Define how credential offers from this issuer should be handled - either automatically (immediate requests sent on receiving offers) or manually (review before requesting). 

Using the API:

POST {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/trustLists
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "catena-x-portal",
    "payload": {
      "name": "issuer",
      "did": "{issuerDID}",
      "ignoreMissingHashlist": false,
      "credentialTypeConfiguration": [
        {
        "credentialType": "MembershipCredential",
        "autoAcceptOffers": false
        },        {
        "credentialType": "CompanyCredential",
        "autoAcceptOffers": true
        }
      ] 
    }
}

Note:

If no credential types appear in the selection list, it means that the issuer has not published supported credential types in the metadata endpoint of their issuer service. In this case, you may need to contact the issuer or wait for updated metadata.

Once configured, the wallet will use this trust information to both verify credentials from the issuer and to handle credential requests and offers according to your preferences.

Conclusion

By extending your Decentralized Identity Verification wallet with a trust configuration, you empower verifiers to confidently validate credentials from trusted issuers while giving holders seamless control over requesting and managing verifiable credentials. This dual-function trust list enhances both security and user experience, supporting flexible workflows for automatic or manual processing of credential offers.

Next step: 

Read more

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Company identity documentation
  • API documentation in detail

entry.title: Re: How to report on direct reports excluding contingent...
entry.content:
Hello - This is possible.  Depending on your current data source/query design, and your EC configuration, you should be able to set a simple filter on the Direct Reports table where the field Is Contingent Worker = 0.

 

The design above will result in a list of all employees in the Job Information table - and where applicable, identify the direct reports who are not contingent workers.  You could further limit your query to only report people who have direct reports (aka managers) who are not contingent workers by applying a query-level filter for Direct Report User ID is not null.

 

Without any filters you might have data like this:

 

By adding both filters described above, only Alice would be reported, showing Bob and Charlie as her direct reports. This is because only Alice is a people manager of (2) non-contingent workers.

 

Does this achieve your objective?

Thanks,

Nick

entry.title: Re: IP19: Not displaying maint. item w/ call status "Sche...
entry.content:
Hi @sebiemb 

Thank you for the question. Let me walk you through it.

Based on the details you provided, what you observe is usually due to differences in maintenance plan scheduling data or task list handling between systems:

Please note that in QAS, the plan only shows orders already called, because forecasted calls are either not yet generated in MHIS or require the task list flag to be displayed. In SBX, the scheduling seems fully updated, so you see both orders and forecasted packages directly. When you select with task list then QAS forces recalculation from the task list to ensure you see the missing future calls.

I suggest you consider the following:

First, make sure you compare tables MPLA / MPOS / MHIS between SBX and QAS for plan 3371.

Thereafter, In QAS, run the IP10/IP30 to reschedule the plan and generate forecast calls.

Finally, ensure to verify that task list assignment and customizing is aligned between SBX and QAS.

 

Once scheduling data and task list references are synchronized, IP19 will display consistently across both systems.

 

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Maintenance Plan Scheduling Overview

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 C# - Is there a way to simulate clicking on a...
entry.content:
Hello @Peach14 

There’s no SAP B1 UI API method to programmatically click the User-Defined Values UDV/Formatted Search magnifying glass. The only supported trigger is the Shift+F2 hotkey, which you can simulate.

var f  = SBO_Application.Forms.ActiveForm;

var et = (SAPbouiCOM.EditText)f.Items.Item("YOUR_ITEM_UID").Specific;

et.Active = true;                  // give focus to the field

SBO_Application.SendKeys("+(F2)"); // Shift+F2 opens the UDV picker

Your draft form doesn’t execute the query because UDV “Auto Refresh” triggers on item events like focus or validate, not consistently on form load for drafts. This behaviour is intentional.

Robust options

  • Run the query yourself (DI API Recordset) on form open and set et.Value.
  • Or replace UDV with a Choose-From-List (CFL) bound to the field; control conditions in code. This is more reliable on drafts than UDV.

No direct click API; use Shift+F2 as a workaround, but for drafts, prefer CFL or code-executed query.

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Message #s CP288 and CP476 about "Plants belonging to...
entry.content:
Hi @Severino1 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you throug it.

Be aware that the warning you are getting occurs mainly because SAP expects the plants at header and operation level to belong to the same company code. Currently, there is no standard customizing option or path available to deactivate this warning message.

Also, note that the typical approach is to acknowledge the warning and continue if you are aware that the difference is intentional and valid for your business scenario.

For your information, some customers handle this by aligning plants within the same company code or by using the same inspection plan across plants, but this may not always be feasible.

Unfortunately, in your case, SAP does not provide a direct customizing object to suppress this warning explicitly.

Please note, if you require the warning to be suppressed, it might need an enhancement user-exit or BAdI

to handle the message control, but this requires further development effort.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: User Authentication Configuration ArcGIS of SAP Servi...
entry.content:
Hello @rafael_umeda 

Thank you for the question. Let me walk you through it.

To help you implement user authentication for ArcGIS in SAP Service and Asset Manager, note that the configuration is done mainly on two sides. Below are the two procedures.

First is to register the Client Application in ArcGIS. You register your client app on the ArcGIS portal by creating an OAuth 2.0 application. During this step, you provide the redirect URI supplied by SAP Service and Asset Manager and obtain the App ID or Client ID and Client Secret.

Second you configure the SAP Service and Asset Manager or SAP BTP to Use the ArcGIS OAuth Details. Here, you must enter the OAuth credentials such as the client ID, Secret, Redirect URI and configure authentication flow as per the documentation. This configuration enables your SAP system to delegate the desired authentication and obtain tokens to access protected ArcGIS resources.

The summary is ArcGIS registration is done on the ArcGIS side online. The SAP config occurs in Service and Asset Manager / SAP BTP admin tools whilst making use of the credentials from ArcGIS.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Technical Error when calling Project Element Badi
entry.content:
Hello @BryAguado 

That error indicates a key-user BAdI for Project Elements is causing a runtime exception when the Project Manager is changed.

How to troubleshoot S4 HANA Public Cloud

Custom Logic app → filter for Project/Project Element BAdIs (e.g., check before save / update). Open each implementation and use Test to reproduce with the same Project ID. Check the runtime log for the exact line/exception.

Application Logs – Display Logs → filter by time/user/app to see the detailed error context.

Data checks: the new Project Manager must be a valid Employee/Worker Business Partner, active on the change date, and authorised for the company code/org unit used by the project.

If needed, deactivate the suspect implementation (or create a safeguard in code and retry. If it works, fix the BAdI (null checks, date validity, missing reads).

Re-enable and retest; add defensive checks so the logic doesn’t fail on PM changes.

With kind regards

Chuma

  • SAP Help – Custom Logic (Key User Extensibility) and testing/tracing
  • SAP Help – Application Logs – Display Logs
  • SAP Help – Commercial Project / Project Control (Public Cloud) – Key User BAdIs

GenAI assist content (These pages are in the SAP Help Portal for S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition.)

entry.title: Software Architecture Pattern for SAP B1
entry.content:

entry.title: Re: Como agregar nuevos campos a variante del Contenedor...
entry.content:
Hola @jesseniacampos 

Thank you for your question. To add new fields to a Test Data Container (TDC) and use them in a variant in SAP S/4HANA Cloud – Test Automation Tool, please follow these steps:

Expose the fields in the TDC
Test Data Container → Fields → Add / Add Multiple → select and add the required fields → Save.

Update the variant
Test Data Container → Variants → Edit → add the newly added fields as columns → enter the values.

Bind the fields to your test
Manage Your Test Processes → open your test process → Field Binding → map the process fields (left) to the TDC fields (right).

Execute the test
Run the test selecting the TDC and the variant you updated.

Important Notes

  • If a field does not appear in step 1, create or enable it in Custom Fields and Logic, and expose it to OData for the business context used by the test. Then return to the TDC and add it..
  • Only fields exposed by the TDC’s entity/identifier can be added. After changing TDC fields, recheck Field Binding before execution.

Helpful SAP Documentation references

  • Add Fields to a Test Data Container
  • Edit a Variant in a Test Data Container
  • Integrate Test Data Container with Test Your Processes Field Binding
  • Custom Fields and Logic (expose to OData)

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma
